column4: I'm trying to install Ubuntu Netbook 10.04 on a Panasonic Toughbook CF-18.  It gets part way through the install then hangs with a blank screen.  Removing "splash quiet" doesn't help (tho I get to see log msgs till the screen goes blank).  What should I do?
if that's the I8xx seris chipset version, tere isn't a clear solution for it yet.
see i8xx work arounds for possible solutins: https://wiki.ubuntu.com/X/Bugs/Lucidi8xxFreezes
Looking.  Thanks!
Close... but my fail is during initial boot off of the CDROM, so I'm not really able to "edit grub".  I'm trying putting it on the boot line (F6)
I ahve the same problem on my D400, I can't get past Boot. However, 10-10 (Maverick), it does, but there's other issues still, so Im waiting on the release this week I belive to test again.
.. and it still fails, just aftre it starts CUPS.  (yes, I recorded the video with my phone)
Is there any way to tell Ubuntu to install but don't try to start X?
Its annoying, I know, but unfortunately, aside from the workaround I sent you, I know of no other way around it.
Install the server edition, CLI only :-) but that's no good for Desktop obviously.
The workaround doesn't work for me... not on boot from CDRom, which is where I am stuck.
does gthe same bug exist in all 10.04 editions?  Did it exist in 9.10?
Same here, Download the 10-10 maverick ISO, Alfa-2 I think it was, and try that one, It has a later kernal and patches, worth a shot.
Hmmm... how about Fedora?  Same bug?
no idea, I stoppexdd using fedora on Core-4 or so. Also, try 8.04-LTS, that worked well on my D400.
or even up to 9.04, but I prefer the LTS versions for best stability.
Oh, so this is an emergent bug (wasnt in 8.04)...
I had no issues with 8.04 on install or operation.
An older version of Ubuntu (the brown background looks like a bird?  Ibex?  :-) ) seems to boot X just fine.
yes, this bug manifested in a fairly rescent kernel. It's since been resolved at the Dev levels, but not distro levels. 10.10 its fixed Im pretty sure.
Just for the record, Ubuntu 8.10 (Intrepid Ibex) seems to work just fine.  :-)
